list.title: Soft Opening
list.dek: For a fairly minimal electronic album, Soft Opening's roster is comparatively cluttered: Arp and MGMT's Andrew VanWyngarden show up alongside Pearl Necklace's Bryce Hackford and Frank Lyon, who trade in little lo-fi assemblages of synthesizer, field recordings, and loops.

list.title: Tastes the Broom
list.dek: Since 2009, Brattleboro, Vt.'s Happy Jawbone Family Band have released hundreds of songs exploring their lo-fi, disturbed take on whimsy via tiny homegrown labels. Mexican Summer will release their next record, for which this retrospective compilation acts as a primer.

tout.title: A Breathtaking Trip to That Otherside cover art

list.title: A Breathtaking Trip to That Otherside
list.seoTitle: A Breathtaking Trip to That Otherside
list.socialTitle: A Breathtaking Trip to That Otherside
list.promoTitle: A Breathtaking Trip to That Otherside
list.dek: What immediately separates Spit's first official release from the legions of self-styled outsider auteurs rapping to themselves on Bandcamp is his touch as a producer. A Breathtaking Trip is a sullen, antisocial record, but Spit makes being a loner feel like a positively sensual experience.

list.title: Down by the Racetrack EP
list.dek: For Guided by Voices, reuniting wasn't a case of making a quick buck before disappearing again. They're back for the long haul, as proven by last year's trilogy of albums, which they now follow with a typically bizarre, extemporaneous EP-- ahead of another album, naturally.

list.title: Broken English: Deluxe Edition
list.dek: Released in 1979 following periods of homelessness, heroin addiction, and scandal, Marianne Faithfull's opus recovered her from exile and captured a generation's disillusioned comedown. As it receives the Deluxe treatment, Broken English's statement on the simple audacity of survival is still raw enough to make you squirm.

list.title: La Busta Gialla
list.dek: A few days after Minutemen/fIREHOSE legend Mike Watt formed a group with Italian musicians Stefano Pilia and Andrea Belfi, the trio headed off on tour. Their debut is a rickety listen, teetering between tautly composed prog and loosely formed grooves.

list.title: General Dome
list.dek: On their second full-length, the Hudson duo continue to skate their own electric rail between prog and post-punk. A great sense of speed and combustion thrums through the music, which is offset by Arone Dyer's engaging, limber vocal performance.

list.title: The Flower Lane
list.dek: Matt Mondanile's first two Ducktails LPs were cozy, blithely executed indie rock comfort food that occasionally coalesced into semi-structured songs. But with New Jersey power-poppers Big Troubles as his backing band and a handful of choice guests, The Flower Lane is a more sumptuous, agile effort.

list.title: Pillowfight
list.dek: Over a career spanning two decades, Dan "the Automator" Nakamura's influence as a producer has been felt all the way up to the charts. His new project, Pillowfight, is a collaboration with Emily Wells that aims for Nancy Sinatra, but comes off more Lana Del Rey.

list.title: Eight
list.dek: If you followed indie rock with any tenacity in the early 2000s, Radar Bros. was the kind of band that capably hung around the periphery. Their latest record, released as Radar Brothers, is a charming anachronism that functions better as a nostalgic device than any proper case for relevancy.

list.title: Heartthrob
list.dek: The title of Tegan and Sara's seventh album is a reference to how we relate to the objects of our affection as teenagers. Produced by Greg Kurstin (P!nk, Kelly Clarkson, Lily Allen), the concise, radio-friendly collection finds them exploring a populist pop bent.

list.title: The Flower of Life
list.dek: James Fauntleroy has written songs for Frank Ocean, Jordin Sparks, and Rihanna among others, keeping a very low profile as a solo artist. But as vocalist of Chicago producer No ID's side project, Cocaine 80s, he sets their experimental hip-hop and R&B chemistry alight.

list.title: Hardcourage
list.dek: Drew Lustman has made a career out of inhabiting ambivalence, flitting between house and garage, dub and techno, frequently led by his experimental jazz background. But on Hardcourage, he's loosened his thrall to introspection in favor of a newfound openness, and the results are great fun.
list.seoDescription: Drew Lustman has made a career out of inhabiting ambivalence, flitting between house and garage, dub and techno, frequently led by his experimental jazz background. But on Hardcourage, he's loosened his thrall to introspection in favor of a newfound openness, and the results are great fun.

list.dek: The L.A. duo's second album seems to be reporting from three simultaneous decades of rock history. list.title: The Choir, the Army
list.dek: From 2010's Llanos to 2011's Sufferers and Merciless, Mike Shiflet has found new possibilities in his abstract, drone-indebted sound by diving deeper into it. His sense of guidance is palpable, turning The Choir, the Army into a kind of wordless story.

list.promoTitle: The Traditional Fools / Reverse Shark Attack
list.dek: The Traditional Fools, Ty Segall's trashy surf punk LP from 2008, and Reverse Shark Attack, his 2009 collaboration with Mikal Cronin, are an interesting pair of albums to release at the same time. One's a collection of dumb-but-fun rock'n'roll, the other's a spotty series of tracks that owe more to Beefheart than garage*.*

list.title: Lost Sirens
list.dek: As the title implies, the latest New Order release contains extras from the band's Waiting for the Sirens Call era-- their last sessions with Peter Hook. Following tussles over mixes and copyright, they release the leftovers, a remix, and "Hellbent", from 2011's Joy Division/New Order singles cash-in, Total.

list.title: California X
list.dek: This Amherst, MA power-trio's self-titled debut is filled with molasses-thick grunge and burly classic rock that isn't far-off from the mess Dinosaur Jr. have been kicking up off-and-on for 30 years. It's the kind of frantic, desperate record that hits you squarely in the gut.

list.title: Donuts (45 Box Set)
list.dek: The songs on J Dilla's signature production opus, released the week of his death, are miniature lessons in how to take sample-based music and use it to build elaborate suites from the nagging little pieces of songs that stick with you long after you've last listened to them. While Donuts is best experienced as a self-contained album, Stones Throw has gone to the unusual step of reissuing it as a box set of 7" singles, complete with bonus material.

list.title: In Focus?
list.dek: Shugo Tokumaru creates toy-box indie pop with his vast collection of noise makers and a computer. He's been doing this for a while now, with varying degrees of success, but on his fifth album it all comes together in a beautifully sharp series of audio bursts.

list.title: Light Up Gold
list.dek: Parquet Courts are slackers in an almost classical sense, conjuring up just about every post-collegiate, pre-responsibility tendency you can think of. Their music ably mixes skittish post-punk and bedhead-riddled indie rock, a knot of Silkworm-inspired guitar tangles and insistent Wire tempos.

list.title: Fade
list.dek: Deep into their career, Yo La Tengo's sense of craft is intact. Fade, at a tight 10 songs and 46 minutes, is the band's shortest album since 1990's Fakebook; it may tread over some familiar turf, but the relaxed pacing and pleasing melodies belie just how much action is really going on beneath the serene surfaces.

list.title: Return of the Savage
list.dek: Return of the Savage, Harlem-based producer Milo Johnson's first album in nearly 20 years, has its genesis in the same box of floppy discs he put away as Nature Boy in 1993. The result extends his work in deep, gritty, midtempo music that walks the line between disco and house-- under a new, more age-appropriate name.

list.title: The Ballasted Orchestra
list.dek: In the 1990s, Stars of the Lid's Adam Wiltze and Brian McBride were making druggy and internally-focused drone music. On the East Austin, Tex., duo's sophomore album, reissued here on remastered vinyl, they did away with voices and followed their drones to a place where words have no meaning.

list.title: Loyal
list.dek: Of all Jakub Alexander's pursuits and side projects, his work as "low level" ambient act Heathered Pearls is designed to give him a break from his personal anxieties. While tension clearly fed into Loyal, it doesn't give much back out, dealing instead in gentle mood shifts that crystallize over the course of the record.

list.title: Elements of Light
list.dek: Originally conceived as a performance for 2011's Øya festival in Oslo, the recording of Elements of Light is an impressive example of how versatile the lowly bell can be, and offers familiar beats and bass swells from Hendrik Weber's world shot through with giddy-making surprises.

list.dek: The 1992 sophomore album from the Bay Area punk trio found them transitioning from the poppier sound of 1990's Unfun to something darker, grittier, more experimental, and even smarter. This remastered 20th Anniversary reissues appends a couple of bonus tracks to Jawbreaker's ragged call to arms.

list.dek: As a member of other people's bands, Robert Beatty specializes in aggressive, speaker-splitting noise-- which also stretched to his work as an artist of album sleeves. list.dek: Roy Montgomery made some of the most innovative music to come out of New Zealand in the 1980s and 90s, exploring post-punk, drone, and solo guitar, but practically vanished at the turn of the century. He returns with a trebling, chiming score to an imaginary movie about 60s Britrockers, Badfinger.

list.title: Silent Congas
list.dek: Greek producer Larry Gus' work can serve as an index of where sample-based music is right now: repetitive, simply structured grooves that draw a little on a lot of genres. Silent Congas doesn't so much envision a new world as recreates an old one that hardly feels like it existed in the first place.

list.title: Tropical Psychedelics
list.dek: Until now, L.A.'s Eddie Ruscha Jr.-- the progeny of the famed pop artist-- has been reticent about letting the bedroom-woven electronica he makes as Secret Circuit see the light. But the analog components, modular synths, and dusty drum machines of Tropical Psychedelics seems to hint at breakout tendencies.

list.title: Voodoo
list.dek: Twelve years since D'Angelo released his dirt-encrusted soul opus in the first month of the new millennium, we have yet to see a follow-up. Heard now on this 2xLP reissue, Voodoo still stands as a paranoid, mysterious, and challenging statement that somehow managed to scale the industry.

list.dek: The Nashville, Tenn., producer Ren Schofield's newest Container record shows that techno can be sloppy, unordered, punk, and, above all, casual. The best part about LP, though, is that it isn't precious: It's wily, sharp, and thoughtfully brief.

list.title: Lucifer in Dub
list.dek: L.A. neo-psych duo Peaking Lights are about as close as you can get to a modern dub act without actually being one. Their 2012 album Lucifer turned that influence into other strains of cosmic head-trip music, but this follow-up companion piece makes the implicit explicit.

list.title: Satanic Blood
list.dek: One of America's first black metal bands, Von's early demos are clear forebears of the current US scene. After reuniting in 2010, then splitting up again two years later, cofounder Venien has returned on his own with this grueling, sloppy mass of low-fidelity, high-energy metal.

list.title: Tiga Non Stop
list.dek: Away from his productions, Tiga is best known for making niche scenes feel populist. He's done it with electroclash, 80s revivalism, Chicago house pilfering, and tech house's gritty end; on this Non Stop mix, he weaves pug-nosed, gritty dance into a broader pop context.

list.dek: Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness was one of the most generous records of the 90s. Smashing Pumpkins took it upon themselves to make a record that only teenagers could love and for many it was the only one they needed. This mega-deluxe box set pads the original with an additional 64 tracks.

list.title: Black Mamba
list.dek: As Whitehouse noise terrorizer William Bennet's African-inspired project shows, even someone with a fondness for calling songs "I'm Comin' Up Your Ass" can age somewhat gracefully. Oscillating between rudderless drifting and layered, beat-oriented work*, Black Mamba* ties together new and previously released material.

list.title: Super Ultra
list.dek: Making free, internet-giveaway mixtapes suits Charli XCX's image: the dance music association, her debt to M.I.A., and her overall rebellious, anti-authoritarian streak. Super Ultra is her second of 2012, and it's an interesting, if not always successful experiment.

list.title: From the Vaults, Vol. 1
list.dek: From the Vaults, Vol. 1 collects unreleased and rare songs recorded by Kylesa between 2005 and 2012, but nothing here sounds like it was readymade for an ephemera stockpile. The dozen tracks are every bit as crafted as those on the Savannah band's excellent studio albums.

list.title: Dagdrøm
list.dek: The smoggy haze of fuzz and scuzz that permeates the Berlin-based doom-gaze duo's albums is so relentless and all-consuming that it starts to feel as comforting and commonplace as oxygen. Though by Nadja's standards, Dagdrøm starts off unusually serene.

list.title: Desertshore/The Final Report
list.dek: When Genesis P-Orridge quit Throbbing Gristle during their 2010 reunion, the remaining members continued on as X-TG. This release comprises a full cover of Nico's 1970 LP, Desertshore, featuring Antony Hegarty, Marc Almond, Blixa Bargeld, Sasha Gray, and others, plus an original album, The Final Report.

list.title: Bikini Kill EP
list.dek: Two decades later, the Olympia-based punk band's debut EP still sounds like a revolution. The first reissue on Bikini Kill Records feels like an auspiciously timed opportunity to remember something that's come to feel almost secondary to their pervasive legacy: Bikini Kill wrote great punk songs.

list.title: A World Out Of Time

list.title: Jummy
list.dek: The 20-year old British art-house producer's debut reveals a dedication to haze and clutter mostly absent on his early singles. Mixing big, wet drum sounds with short, cloudy bursts of piano and mumbled half-syllables, Jummy refuses to fade into the background.

list.title: The Odds
list.dek: Ian MacKaye and Amy Farina's four-year-old son appears on the cover of their third album as the Evens, their first in six years. A powerful example of aging gracefully, The Odds is the product of scaling down operations rather than of giving up or throwing the fans a nostalgia trip.

list.title: Rare Chandeliers
list.dek: Action Bronson has both the deep imagination and wicked humor required to make his outsized persona as engrossing as it is singular. On paper, the Queens rapper's mixtape with fellow old-school N.Y. revivalist Alchemist should have no trouble living up to expectations.

list.title: The Disintegration Loops
list.dek: The four volumes of William Basinski's ambient masterpiece have been gathered into a gorgeous and impressive  9xLP, 5xCD box set, including two previously unreleased live performances.

list.title: Go Easy
list.dek: The Australian rock quartet, which features three siblings and "a spiritual brother," are still unruly, but everything fits together on Go Easy, their most coherent album to date. The record evokes the way mid-90s Royal Trux made rock sound primitive while still mining its history.

list.title: Growing Seeds
list.dek: Swedish electronic musician and singer Hannes Norrvide's dark post-punk minimal wave has the obsessive feel of something banged out in one demented trance. His debut, Growing Seeds, hits the same nagging sweet spot as the most hypnotically driving 8-bit music.

list.title: Relief
list.dek: Relief, a single 36-minute song that wrestles hectic squirming into an impregnable monument, may be Chicago noise artist Kevin Drumm's next milestone. Even during its most violent passages, it's more entrancing than overwhelming.

list.title: Cosmic Angel: The Illuminati Prince/ss
list.dek: Following a sinister, hallucinatory handful of one-off tracks, the charismatic N.Y. poet and performance artist Michael Quattlebaum's first Mykki Blanco full-length is a grab-bag of experimentation tailored to 2012's increasingly blurry rap landscape.

list.title: King Animal
list.dek: The mega-selling grunge band's recent reunion has a par-for-the-course, procedural air: Soundgarden are back together and making new music because, well, that's what dormant alt-rock institutions are supposed to do now, right?
